concern: Do any fellow psychology majors get caught in extreme self-doubt about their future? I'm so scared I won't achieve my dreams of being a psychologist. It's a long road and I thought I was ready and I want it more than anything but holy shit I'm so scared something will go wrong. I'm scared I don't have what it takes or I don't stand out enough. I'm a freshman and I think I'm doing well but I keep getting that intrusive feeling. Anyone else feel like this? Is this normal? Will it start to make sense soon?

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Im here to listen. Whats been on your mind lately?
I've been dealing with a lot of self-doubt about my future path lately. It's making me question if these feelings are typical for someone in my situation.

It sounds like you're feeling uncertain and a bit lost. That's completely normal when you're trying to figure out your future. It can be a lot to process and it's natural to have doubts. Would you like to talk more about what's been causing these feelings?
Yes, I'd like to talk more about these feelings, as they keep creeping up and affecting my confidence. It's hard to shake off the worry that I'm not on the right track.

It can be really tough to manage those feelings of self-doubt, especially when they start to impact your confidence. It's important to remember that it's normal to have these feelings, and it doesn't necessarily mean you're on the wrong path. Sometimes, it's just part of the process of figuring out what you want and where you're headed. Do you have any specific concerns about your future path that are contributing to these feelings of doubt?
Yes, I have concerns about whether I'll have the skills and resilience needed for my future goals. These doubts often make me feel like I might not be capable enough to succeed.

It's understandable to have concerns about your abilities and resilience as you work towards your future goals. Many people experience these doubts, and it's important to acknowledge them. However, it's also essential to remember that skills can be developed and resilience can be built over time. Have you considered any steps you might take to address these concerns and help you feel more confident in your abilities?

I've thought about talking to my academic advisor for guidance and trying to join psychology-related clubs to gain more practical experience. These steps might help me build the resilience I worry I lack, but the doubts still linger despite my efforts.

It's great to hear that you're considering proactive steps like talking to your academic advisor and joining relevant clubs. Engaging with your field of interest and seeking guidance can indeed help you develop your skills and resilience. However, it's important to remember that building confidence takes time, and it's okay to have lingering doubts even as you take these steps. It might be helpful to explore any specific experiences or thoughts that might be contributing to these persistent doubts. Is there anything in particular that makes you feel like you might not be capable enough, despite your efforts?

I sometimes feel like my lack of prior experience in psychology makes me doubt my capabilities, even with my current efforts. Additionally, I worry that I don't possess standout qualities that could help me succeed in such a competitive field.

It's natural to feel concerned about your capabilities when entering a new field, especially one as competitive as psychology. However, it's important to remember that everyone starts somewhere, and your current efforts to engage with the field and seek guidance are valuable steps towards building the experience and confidence you desire. As for standout qualities, it might be helpful to explore your unique strengths and perspectives that could bring a fresh approach to the field. Is there anything about your background or interests that you feel might contribute to your success in psychology, even if it doesn't seem directly related?

I think my background in volunteering at a community center has helped me develop empathy and communication skills, which could be assets in psychology. Even so, I'm not sure if that's enough to truly stand out in such a competitive field.

It's encouraging to hear that you recognize the value of your volunteering background in developing crucial skills for psychology, such as empathy and communication. While it's understandable to worry about standing out in a competitive field, remember that there's no one specific formula for success. Your unique combination of skills, experiences, and perspectives, including your volunteering background, can bring a valuable perspective to the field. It's also worth noting that many successful professionals in psychology come from diverse backgrounds and experiences. Building on your strengths and finding ways to apply them in your academic and professional pursuits can help you carve out your own path in the field. Have you considered ways in which your volunteering experience might be integrated into your future psychology career or academic journey?

I've thought about using my volunteering experience to pursue related internships or research opportunities in psychology, which could help build my resume. However, I'm still unsure if that will be enough to make me stand out in such a competitive field.

Pursuing internships or research opportunities related to your volunteering experience is an excellent idea. These opportunities can not only enhance your resume but also provide valuable hands-on experience and networking connections. While it's normal to have doubts about standing out in a competitive field, remember that every step you take contributes to your growth and development as a professional. Instead of focusing on the end goal of standing out, consider embracing the journey of learning and growth. Have you thought about reaching out to professionals in the field who might offer guidance on how to best leverage your unique background and experiences?

I've considered reaching out to professionals for guidance on leveraging my background, but I'm worried it might not be enough to help me stand out. Still, I'm open to trying it as a way to build more confidence in my path forward.

Reaching out to professionals can be a valuable way to gain insights and guidance, even if it may not provide a definitive solution. Remember that building confidence in your path forward is a process, and each step, including seeking guidance, contributes to that process. When you're ready, consider compiling a list of professionals whose work aligns with your interests, and think about specific questions you'd like to ask them about leveraging your background. Which professionals would you consider contacting, and what questions might you ask to help you gain clarity on your path?

I might consider contacting my psychology professors or alumni from my university who have gone into the field, as they could relate to my experiences. I'd ask them about specific strategies to highlight my unique background in applications and how they overcame similar doubts to succeed in their careers.

It's great to see that you have a plan in place to reach out to professionals for guidance. Remember that your unique experiences and background can be an asset in your journey, and seeking advice from those who have been in your position can provide valuable insights. Stay committed to your path and continue taking steps towards building your confidence and resilience. Keep in mind that it's natural to have doubts, but each step you take brings you closer to your goals. I encourage you to follow through with your plan and reach out to your professors and alumni. Good luck, and feel free to provide updates on your progress during our next contact. Let's schedule a follow-up in about a month to check in on your progress and discuss any new developments or concerns you may have.
Thank you, I'll reach out to my professors and alumni as planned, even though my doubts about standing out still linger. I'll look forward to our follow-up in a month to share how it's going.
